1.verse: Then Job said in reply:

2.verse: At least listen to my words, and let that be the consolation you offer.

3.verse: Bear with me while I speak; and after I have spoken, you can mock!

4.verse: Is my complaint toward man? And why should I not be impatient?

5.verse: Look at me and be astonished, put your hands over your mouths.

6.verse: When I think of it, I am dismayed, and horror takes hold on my flesh.

7.verse: Why do the wicked survive, grow old, become mighty in power?

8.verse: Their progeny is secure in their sight; they see before them their kinsfolk and their offspring.

9.verse: Their homes are safe and without fear, nor is the scourge of God upon them.

10.verse: Their bulls gender without fail; their cows calve and do not miscarry.

11.verse: These folk have infants numerous as lambs, and their children dance.

12.verse: They sing to the timbrel and harp, and make merry to the sound of the flute.

13.verse: They live out their days in prosperity, and tranquilly go down to the nether world.

14.verse: Yet they say to God, "Depart from us, for we have no wish to learn your ways!

15.verse: What is the Almighty that we should serve him? And what gain shall we have if we pray to him?"

16.verse: If their happiness is not in their own hands and if the counsel of the wicked is repulsive to God,

17.verse: How often is the lamp of the wicked put out? How often does destruction come upon them, the portion he allots in his anger?

18.verse: Let them be like straw before the wind, and like chaff which the storm snatches away!

19.verse: May God not store up the man's misery for his children; let him requite the man himself so that he feels it,

20.verse: Let his own eyes see the calamity, and the wrath of the Almighty let him drink!

21.verse: For what interest has he in his family after him, when the number of his months is finished?

22.verse: Can anyone teach God knowledge, seeing that he judges those on high?

23.verse: One dies in his full vigor, wholly at ease and content;

24.verse: His figure is full and nourished, and his bones are rich in marrow.

25.verse: Another dies in bitterness of soul, having never tasted happiness.

26.verse: Alike they lie down in the dust, and worms cover them both.

27.verse: Behold, I know your thoughts, and the arguments you rehearse against me.

28.verse: For you say, "Where is the house of the magnate, and where the dwelling place of the wicked?"

29.verse: Have you not asked the wayfarers and do you not recognize their monuments?

30.verse: Nay, the evil man is spared calamity when it comes;

32.verse: and on the day he is carried to the grave

31.verse: Who will charge him with his conduct to his face, and for what he has done who will repay him?

33.verse: Sweet to him are the clods of the valley, and over him the funeral mound keeps watch, While all the line of mankind follows him, and the countless others who have gone before.

34.verse: How then can you offer me vain comfort, while in your answers perfidy remains?

annotations.1: [22] Those on high: the angels.

1.verse: Then the LORD addressed Job out of the storm and said:

2.verse: Who is this that obscures divine plans with words of ignorance?

3.verse: Gird up your loins now, like a man; I will question you, and you tell me the answers!

4.verse: Where were you when I founded the earth? Tell me, if you have understanding.

5.verse: Who determined its size; do you know? Who stretched out the measuring line for it?

6.verse: Into what were its pedestals sunk, and who laid the cornerstone,

7.verse: While the morning stars sang in chorus and all the sons of God shouted for joy?

8.verse: And who shut within doors the sea, when it burst forth from the womb;

9.verse: When I made the clouds its garment and thick darkness its swaddling bands?

10.verse: When I set limits for it and fastened the bar of its door,

11.verse: And said: Thus far shall you come but no farther, and here shall your proud waves be stilled!

12.verse: Have you ever in your lifetime commanded the morning and shown the dawn its place

13.verse: For taking hold of the ends of the earth, till the wicked are shaken from its surface?

14.verse: The earth is changed as is clay by the seal, and dyed as though it were a garment;

15.verse: But from the wicked the light is withheld, and the arm of pride is shattered.

16.verse: Have you entered into the sources of the sea, or walked about in the depths of the abyss?

17.verse: Have the gates of death been shown to you, or have you seen the gates of darkness?

18.verse: Have you comprehended the breadth of the earth? Tell me, if you know all:

19.verse: Which is the way to the dwelling place of light, and where is the abode of darkness,

20.verse: That you may take them to their boundaries and set them on their homeward paths?

21.verse: You know, because you were born before them, and the number of your years is great!

22.verse: Have you entered the storehouse of the snow, and seen the treasury of the hail

23.verse: Which I have reserved for times of stress, for the days of war and of battle?

24.verse: Which way to the parting of the winds, whence the east wind spreads over the earth?

25.verse: Who has laid out a channel for the downpour and for the thunderstorm a path

26.verse: To bring rain to no man's land, the unpeopled wilderness;

27.verse: To enrich the waste and desolate ground till the desert blooms with verdure?

28.verse: Has the rain a father; or who has begotten the drops of dew?

29.verse: Out of whose womb comes the ice, and who gives the hoarfrost its birth in the skies,

30.verse: When the waters lie covered as though with stone that holds captive the surface of the deep?

31.verse: Have you fitted a curb to the Pleiades, or loosened the bonds of Orion?

32.verse: Can you bring forth the Mazzaroth in their season, or guide the Bear with its train?

33.verse: Do you know the ordinances of the heavens; can you put into effect their plan on the earth?

34.verse: Can you raise your voice among the clouds, or veil yourself in the waters of the storm?

35.verse: Can you send forth the lightnings on their way, or will they say to you, "Here we are"?

37.verse: Who counts the clouds in his wisdom? Or who tilts the water jars of heaven

38.verse: So that the dust of earth is fused into a mass and its clods made solid?

39.verse: Do you hunt the prey for the lioness or appease the hunger of her cubs,

40.verse: While they crouch in their dens, or lie in wait in the thicket?

36.verse: Who puts wisdom in the heart, and gives the cock its understanding?

41.verse: Who provides nourishment for the ravens when their young ones cry out to God, and they rove abroad without food?

annotations.1: [1] Now the LORD enters the debate and addresses two discourses (Job 38-39 and Job 40-41) to Job, in which he speaks of his wisdom and power, which are altogether beyond the capacity of Job, who therefore should never dare to demand a reason for the divine actions. Out of the storm: frequently the background of the appearances of the LORD in the Old Testament; cf Psalm 18; 50; Nahum 1:3; Hebrews 3.
annotations.2: [3] Gird up your loins: prepare for combat - figuratively, be ready to defend yourself in debate
annotations.3: [7] Sons of God: angels; cf Job 1:6
annotations.5: [22-23] Hail . . . of war: thus God used a hailstorm to rout Joshua's foes in the battle of Gibeon; cf Joshua 10:11; Sirach 46:5
annotations.6: [31-32] Pleiades . . . Orion . . . Bear: cf Job 9:9. Mazzaroth: It is uncertain what astronomical group is meant by this Hebrew word; perhaps a southern constellation (cf Job 9:9)
annotations.7: [34] Veil yourself . . . storm: wrap yourself in a cloud, as God comes in a theophany; cf Psalm 18:12
annotations.8: [35] Here we are: at your service
annotations.9: [36] Understanding: the reflection of divine Wisdom discernible in the created animal instincts of the cock

2.verse: But what is man's lot from God above, his inheritance from the Almighty on high?

3.verse: Is it not calamity for the unrighteous, and woe for evildoers?

4.verse: Does he not see my ways, and number all my steps?

6.verse: Let God weigh me in the scales of justice; thus will he know my innocence!

5.verse: If I have walked in falsehood and my foot has hastened to deceit;

7.verse: If my steps have turned out of the way, and my heart has followed my eyes, or any stain clings to my hands,

8.verse: Then may I sow, but another eat of it, or may my planting be rooted up!

38.verse: If my land has cried out against me till its very furrows complained;

39.verse: If I have eaten its produce without payment and grieved the hearts of its tenants;

40.verse: Then let the thistles grow instead of wheat and noxious weeds instead of barley!

1.verse: If I have made an agreement with my eyes and entertained any thoughts against a maiden;

9.verse: If my heart has been enticed toward a woman, and I have lain in wait at my neighbor's door;

10.verse: Then may my wife grind for another, and may others cohabit with her!

11.verse: For that would be heinous, a crime to be condemned;

12.verse: A fire that should burn down to the abyss till it consumed all my possessions to the roots.

13.verse: Had I refused justice to my manservant or to my maid, when they had a claim against me,

14.verse: What then should I do when God rose up; what could I answer when he demanded an account?

15.verse: Did not he who made me in the womb make him? Did not the same One fashion us before our birth?

16.verse: If I have denied anything to the poor, or allowed the eyes of the widow to languish

17.verse: While I ate my portion alone, with no share in it for the fatherless,

18.verse: Though like a father God has reared me from my youth, guiding me even from my mother's womb -

19.verse: If I have seen a wanderer without clothing, or a poor man without covering,

20.verse: Whose limbs have not blessed me when warmed with the fleece of my sheep;

21.verse: If I have raised my hand against the innocent because I saw that I had supporters at the gate -

22.verse: Then may my arm fall from the shoulder, my forearm be broken at the elbow!

23.verse: For the dread of God will be upon me, and his majesty will overpower me.

24.verse: Had I put my trust in gold or called fine gold my security;

25.verse: Or had I rejoiced that my wealth was great, or that my hand had acquired abundance -

26.verse: Had I looked upon the sun as it shone, or the moon in the splendor of its progress,

27.verse: And had my heart been secretly enticed to waft them a kiss with my hand;

28.verse: This too would be a crime for condemnation, for I should have denied God above.

29.verse: Had I rejoiced at the destruction of my enemy or exulted when evil fell upon him,

30.verse: Even though I had not suffered my mouth to sin by uttering a curse against his life -

31.verse: Had not the men of my tent exclaimed, "Who has not been fed with his meat!"

32.verse: Because no stranger lodged in the street, but I opened my door to wayfarers -

33.verse: Had I, out of human weakness, hidden my sins and buried my guilt in my bosom

34.verse: Because I feared the noisy multitude and the scorn of the tribes terrified me - then I should have remained silent, and not come out of doors!

35.verse: Oh, that I had one to hear my case, and that my accuser would write out his indictment!

36.verse: Surely, I should wear it on my shoulder or put it on me like a diadem;

37.verse: Of all my steps I should give him an account; like a prince I should present myself before him. This is my final plea; let the Almighty answer me! The words of Job are ended.

annotations.1: [6-34] Job's final protestation of his innocence.
annotations.2: [8,9] Note the gradation: avoidance of sinful glances and thoughts against a maiden; desire for another's wife
annotations.3: [21] Gate: cf notes on Job 5:4; Ruth 4:1
annotations.4: [26-28] Job never sinned by worshiping the sun or the moon; waft them a kiss: an act of idolatrous worship
annotations.5: [31] The members of his household will testify to his hospitality
annotations.6: [33,34] Job's present protest is made, not in spite of hidden sins which he had been unwilling to disclose, but out of genuine innocence
annotations.7: [36] On my shoulder: i.e., boldly, proudly
annotations.8: [37] Like a prince: not as a frightened criminal. Final plea: literally, "tau," the last letter of the Hebrew alphabet; in the current Hebrew text this line is in Job 31:35, while the following one ends Job 31:40

1.verse: Once again the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan also came with them.

2.verse: And the LORD said to Satan, "Whence do you come?" And Satan answered the LORD and said, "From roaming the earth and patrolling it."

3.verse: And the LORD said to Satan, "Have you noticed my servant Job, and that there is no one on earth like him, faultless and upright, fearing God and avoiding evil? He still holds fast to his innocence although you incited me against him to ruin him without cause."

4.verse: And Satan answered the LORD and said, "Skin for skin! All that a man has will he give for his life.

5.verse: But now put forth your hand and touch his bone and his flesh, and surely he will blaspheme you to your face."

6.verse: And the LORD said to Satan, "He is in your power; only spare his life."

7.verse: So Satan went forth from the presence of the LORD and smote Job with severe boils from the soles of his feet to the crown of his head.

8.verse: And he took a potsherd to scrape himself, as he sat among the ashes.

9.verse: Then his wife said to him, "Are you still holding to your innocence? Curse God and die."

10.verse: But he said to her, "Are even you going to speak as senseless women do? We accept good things from God; and should we not accept evil?" Through all this, Job said nothing sinful.

11.verse: Now when three of Job's friends heard of all the misfortune that had come upon him, they set out each one from his own place: Eliphaz from Teman, Bildad from Shuh, and Zophar from Naamath. They met and journeyed together to give him sympathy and comfort.

12.verse: But when, at a distance, they lifted up their eyes and did not recognize him, they began to weep aloud; they tore their cloaks and threw dust upon their heads.

13.verse: Then they sat down upon the ground with him seven days and seven nights, but none of them spoke a word to him; for they saw how great was his suffering.

annotations.1: [4] Skin for skin: an expression which, as applied to Job, means that he has borne his suffering patiently thus far only because he seeks to avoid greater suffering and to receive greater favors from God.
annotations.2: [9] Curse God and die: you have nothing to hope for from God and therefore nothing to live for
annotations.3: [11] The names of Job's friends suggest Edomite origin. The Edomites ( Obadiah 1:8-9) and more specifically the Temanites ( Jeremiah 49:7) enjoyed a reputation for wisdom

1.verse: Then Job replied and said:

2.verse: No doubt you are the intelligent folk, and with you wisdom shall die!

3.verse: But I have intelligence as well as you; for who does not know such things as these?

4.verse: I have become the sport of my neighbors: "The one whom God answers when he calls upon him, The just, the perfect man," is a laughing-stock;

5.verse: The undisturbed esteem my downfall a disgrace such as awaits unsteady feet;

6.verse: Yet the tents of robbers are prosperous, and those who provoke God are secure.

7.verse: But now ask the beasts to teach you, and the birds of the air to tell you;

8.verse: Or the reptiles on earth to instruct you, and the fish of the sea to inform you.

9.verse: Which of all these does not know that the hand of God has done this?

10.verse: In his hand is the soul of every living thing, and the life breath of all mankind.

11.verse: Does not the ear judge words as the mouth tastes food?

12.verse: So with old age is wisdom, and with length of days understanding.

13.verse: With him are wisdom and might; his are counsel and understanding.

14.verse: If he breaks a thing down, there is no rebuilding; if he imprisons a man, there is no release.

15.verse: He holds back the waters and there is drought; he sends them forth and they overwhelm the land.

16.verse: With him are strength and prudence; the misled and the misleaders are his.

17.verse: He sends counselors away barefoot, and of judges he makes fools.

18.verse: He loosens the bonds imposed by kings and leaves but a waistcloth to bind the king's own loins.

19.verse: and lets their never-failing waters flow away.

20.verse: He silences the trusted adviser, and takes discretion from the aged.

21.verse: He breaks down the barriers of the streams

22.verse: The recesses of the darkness he discloses, and brings the gloom forth to the light.

23.verse: He makes nations great and he destroys them; he spreads peoples abroad and he abandons them.

24.verse: He takes understanding from the leaders of the land,

25.verse: till they grope in the darkness without light; he makes them stagger like drunken men.

annotations.1: [4-5] The Hebrew is somewhat obscure, but the general sense is that the wicked mock at the pious when the latter appear to be abandoned by God; cf Psalm 22:7-9; Matthew 27:39-43.
annotations.2: [18] (18)Waistcloth . . . loins: he reduces kings to the condition of slaves, who wear only a cloth wrapped about the waist

1.verse: Then Job answered the LORD and said:

2.verse: I know that you can do all things, and that no purpose of yours can be hindered.

3.verse: I have dealt with great things that I do not understand; things too wonderful for me, which I cannot know.

5.verse: I had heard of you by word of mouth, but now my eye has seen you.

6.verse: Therefore I disown what I have said, and repent in dust and ashes.

7.verse: And it came to pass after the LORD had spoken these words to Job, that the LORD said to Eliphaz the Temanite, "I am angry with you and with your two friends; for you have not spoken rightly concerning me, as has my servant Job.

8.verse: Now, therefore, take seven bullocks and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and offer up a holocaust for yourselves; and let my servant Job pray for you; for his prayer I will accept, not to punish you severely. For you have not spoken rightly concerning me, as has my servant Job."

9.verse: Then Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite, went and did as the LORD had commanded them. And the LORD accepted the intercession of Job.

10.verse: Also, the LORD restored the prosperity of Job, after he had prayed for his friends; the LORD even gave to Job twice as much as he had before.

11.verse: Then all his brethren and his sisters came to him, and all his former acquaintances, and they dined with him in his house. They condoled with him and comforted him for all the evil which the LORD had brought upon him; and each one gave him a piece of money and a gold ring.

12.verse: Thus the LORD blessed the latter days of Job more than his earlier ones. For he had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand she-asses.

13.verse: And he had seven sons and three daughters,

14.verse: of whom he called the first Jemimah, the second Keziah, and the third Keren-happuch.

15.verse: In all the land no other women were as beautiful as the daughters of Job; and their father gave them an inheritance among their brethren.

16.verse: After this, Job lived a hundred and forty years; and he saw his children, his grandchildren, and even his great-grandchildren.

17.verse: Then Job died, old and full of years.

annotations.1: [2-6] In the current Hebrew text, this final utterance of Job is interrupted by words ascribed to God ( Job 42:3-4) which are in large part a duplication of Job 38:2-3.
annotations.2: [7] The three friends of Job (Elihu is ignored in the Epilogue) are criticized by the LORD because they had (even though in good faith) leveled false charges against him
annotations.3: [8] Job becomes the intercessor for his friends, as were other great Old Testament characters, e.g., Abraham and Moses, and as our Lord would be, whom he prefigured. Seven: a symbolic number
annotations.4: [11] A piece of money: the term is the same as that used in Genesis 33:19; Joshua 24:32. Gold ring: for the nose or ear
annotations.5: [14] Job's daughters had names symbolic of their charms: Jemimah, dove; Keziah, precious perfume (cf Psalm 45:9); Kerenhappuch, cosmetic jar-more precisely, a container for a black powder that was used like modern mascara
annotations.6: [15] Ordinarily daughters did not inherit property unless there were no sons; cf Numbers 27:1-11
annotations.7: [16] As his other rewards were twice as much as he had before ( Job 42:10) so Job's hundred and forty years were double the expected span of human life; cf Psalm 90:10

1.verse: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:

2.verse: Can a man be profitable to God? Though to himself a wise man be profitable!

3.verse: Is it of advantage to the Almighty if you are just? Or is it a gain to him if you make your ways perfect?

4.verse: Is it because of your piety that he reproves you - that he enters with you into judgment?

5.verse: Is not your wickedness manifold? Are not your iniquities endless?

6.verse: You have unjustly kept your kinsmen's goods in pawn, left them stripped naked of their clothing.

7.verse: To the thirsty you have given no water to drink, and from the hungry you have withheld bread;

8.verse: As if the land belonged to the man of might, and only the privileged were to dwell in it.

9.verse: You have sent widows away empty-handed, and the resources of orphans you have destroyed.

10.verse: Therefore snares are round about you, and a sudden terror causes you dismay,

11.verse: Or darkness, in which you cannot see; a deluge of waters covers you.

12.verse: Does not God, in the heights of the heavens, behold the stars, high though they are?

13.verse: Yet you say, "What does God know? Can he judge through the thick darkness?

14.verse: Clouds hide him so that he cannot see; he walks upon the vault of the heavens!"

15.verse: Do you indeed keep to the ancient way trodden by worthless men,

16.verse: Who were snatched away before their time; whose foundations a flood swept away?

17.verse: These men said to God, "Depart from us!" and, "What can the Almighty do to us?"

18.verse: (Yet he had filled their houses with good things! But far be from me the mind of the impious!)

19.verse: The just look on and are gladdened, and the innocent deride them:

20.verse: "Truly these have been destroyed where they stood, and such as were left, fire has consumed!"

21.verse: Come to terms with him to be at peace. In this shall good come to you:

22.verse: Receive instruction from his mouth, and lay up his words in your heart.

23.verse: If you return to the Almighty, you will be restored; if you put iniquity far from your tent,

24.verse: And treat raw gold like dust, and the fine gold of Ophir as pebbles from the brook,

25.verse: Then the Almighty himself shall be your gold and your sparkling silver.

26.verse: For then you shall delight in the Almighty and you shall lift up your face toward God.

27.verse: You shall entreat him and he will hear you, and your vows you shall fulfill.

28.verse: When you make a decision, it shall succeed for you, and upon your ways the light shall shine.

29.verse: For he brings down the pride of the haughty, but the man of humble mien he saves.

30.verse: God delivers him who is innocent; you shall be delivered through cleanness of hands.

annotations.1: [6-8] This criticism of Job by Eliphaz is altogether untrue, but it is made to dramatize the latter's argument that God always acts justly when he causes someone to suffer. Job 22:8 is misplaced.
annotations.2: [18] A gloss, taken partly from Job 21:16

1.verse: Then Job answered and said:

2.verse: Ah, could my anguish but be measured and my calamity laid with it in the scales,

3.verse: They would now outweigh the sands of the sea! Because of this I speak without restraint.

4.verse: For the arrows of the Almighty pierce me, and my spirit drinks in their poison; the terrors of God are arrayed against me.

5.verse: Does the wild ass bray when he has grass? Does the ox low over his fodder?

6.verse: Can a thing insipid be eaten without salt? Is there flavor in the white of an egg?

7.verse: I refuse to touch them; they are loathsome food to me.

8.verse: Oh, that I might have my request, and that God would grant what I long for:

9.verse: Even that God would decide to crush me, that he would put forth his hand and cut me off!

10.verse: Then I should still have consolation and could exult through unremitting pain, because I have not transgressed the commands of the Holy One.

11.verse: What strength have I that I should endure, and what is my limit that I should be patient?

12.verse: Have I the strength of stones, or is my flesh of bronze?

13.verse: Have I no helper, and has advice deserted me?

14.verse: A friend owes kindness to one in despair, though he have forsaken the fear of the Almighty.

15.verse: My brethren are undependable as a brook, as watercourses that run dry in the wadies;

16.verse: Though they may be black with ice, and with snow heaped upon them,

17.verse: Yet once they flow, they cease to be; in the heat, they disappear from their place.

18.verse: Caravans turn aside from their routes; they go into the desert and perish.

19.verse: The caravans of Tema search, the companies of Sheba have hopes;

20.verse: They are disappointed, though they were confident; they come there and are frustrated.

21.verse: It is thus that you have now become for me; you see a terrifying thing and are afraid.

22.verse: Have I asked you to give me anything, to offer a gift for me from your possessions,

23.verse: Or to deliver me from the enemy, or to redeem me from oppressors?

24.verse: Teach me, and I will be silent; prove to me wherein I have erred.

25.verse: How agreeable are honest words; yet how unconvincing is your argument!

26.verse: Do you consider your words as proof, but the sayings of a desperate man as wind?

27.verse: You would even cast lots for the orphan, and would barter away your friend!

28.verse: Come, now, give me your attention; surely I will not lie to your face.

29.verse: Think it over; let there be no injustice. Think it over; I still am right.

30.verse: Is there insincerity on my tongue, or cannot my taste discern falsehood?

annotations.1: [5-6] Job would not complain if his life were as pleasant to him as fodder to a hungry animal; but his life is as disagreeable as insipid food. White of an egg: thus the obscure Hebrew has been understood in Jewish tradition; some render it "mallow juice."
annotations.2: [19] Tema: in northwest Arabia. Sheba: see note on Job 1:15

1.verse: Lo, all this my eye has seen; my ear has heard and perceived it.

2.verse: What you know, I also know; I fall not short of you.

3.verse: But I would speak with the Almighty; I wish to reason with God.

4.verse: You are glossing over falsehoods and offering vain remedies, every one of you!

5.verse: Oh, that you would be altogether silent! This for you would be wisdom.

6.verse: Hear now the rebuke I shall utter and listen to the reproof from my lips.

7.verse: Is it for God that you speak falsehood? Is it for him that you utter deceit?

8.verse: Is it for him that you show partiality? Do you play advocate on behalf of God?

9.verse: Will it be well when he shall search you out? Would you impose on him as one does on men?

10.verse: He will openly rebuke you if even in secret you show partiality.

11.verse: Surely will his majesty affright you and the dread of him fall upon you.

12.verse: Your reminders are ashy maxims, your fabrications are mounds of clay.

13.verse: Be silent, let me alone! that I may speak and give vent to my feelings.

14.verse: I will carry my flesh between my teeth, and take my life in my hand.

15.verse: Slay me though he might, I will wait for him; I will defend my conduct before him.

16.verse: And this shall be my salvation, that no impious man can come into his presence.

17.verse: Pay careful heed to my speech, and give my statement a hearing.

18.verse: Behold, I have prepared my case, I know that I am in the right.

19.verse: If anyone can make a case against me, then I shall be silent and die.

20.verse: These things only do not use against me, then from your presence I need not hide:

21.verse: Withdraw your hand far from me, and let not the terror of you frighten me.

22.verse: Then call me, and I will respond; or let me speak first, and answer me.

23.verse: What are my faults and my sins? My misdeeds and my sins make known to me!

24.verse: Why do you hide your face and consider me your enemy?

25.verse: Will you harass a wind-driven leaf, or pursue a withered straw?

26.verse: For you draw up bitter indictments against me, and punish in me the faults of my youth.

27.verse: You put my feet in the stocks; you watch all my paths and trace out all my footsteps.

28.verse: Though he wears out like a leather bottle, like a garment that the moth has consumed?

Job is so confident of his innocence that he is willing to risk his life by going to judgment with God.
annotations.2: [20] From here to the end of Job 14 Job pleads his case, addressing God rather than his three friends

annotations.2: [17] The asterisks which follow this verse mark off a passage ( Job 24:18-24) which cannot be ascribed to Job with certainty. Job 24:17-24 are in general poorly preserved; and much of Job 24:18-21 has not been translated because these verses are obscure. St. Jerome renders them as follows: (18) "He is light upon the face of the water, cursed be his portion on the earth; let him not walk by the way of vineyards. (19) Let him pass from the snow waters to excessive heat, and his sin even to hell. 1.verse: In the land of Uz there was a blameless and upright man named Job, who feared God and avoided evil.

2.verse: Seven sons and three daughters were born to him;

3.verse: and he had seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred she-asses, and a great number of work animals, so that he was greater than any of the men of the East.

4.verse: His sons used to take turns giving feasts, sending invitations to their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

5.verse: And when each feast had run its course, Job would send for them and sanctify them, rising early and offering holocausts for every one of them. For Job said, "It may be that my sons have sinned and blasphemed God in their hearts." This Job did habitually.

6.verse: One day, when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, Satan also came among them.

7.verse: And the LORD said to Satan, "Whence do you come?" Then Satan answered the LORD and said, "From roaming the earth and patrolling it."

8.verse: And the LORD said to Satan, "Have you noticed my servant Job, and that there is no one on earth like him, blameless and upright, fearing God and avoiding evil?"

9.verse: But Satan answered the LORD and said, "Is it for nothing that Job is God-fearing?

10.verse: Have you not surrounded him and his family and all that he has with your protection? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his livestock are spread over the land.

11.verse: But now put forth your hand and touch anything that he has, and surely he will blaspheme you to your face."

12.verse: And the LORD said to Satan, "Behold, all that he has is in your power; only do not lay a hand upon his person." So Satan went forth from the presence of the LORD.

13.verse: And so one day, while his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in the house of their eldest brother,

14.verse: a messenger came to Job and said, "The oxen were plowing and the asses grazing beside them,

15.verse: and the Sabeans carried them off in a raid. They put the herdsmen to the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you."

16.verse: While he was yet speaking, another came and said, "Lightning has fallen from heaven and struck the sheep and their shepherds and consumed them; and I alone have escaped to tell you."

17.verse: While he was yet speaking, another came and said, "The Chaldeans formed three columns, seized the camels, carried them off, and put those tending them to the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you."

18.verse: While he was yet speaking, another came and said, "Your sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in the house of their eldest brother,

19.verse: when suddenly a great wind came across the desert and smote the four corners of the house. It fell upon the young people and they are dead; and I alone have escaped to tell you."

20.verse: Then Job began to tear his cloak and cut off his hair. He cast himself prostrate upon the ground,

21.verse: and said, "Naked I came forth from my mother's womb, and naked shall I go back again. The LORD gave and the LORD has taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD!"

22.verse: In all this Job did not sin, nor did he say anything disrespectful of God.

annotations.1: [2] Elihu means "My God is he." This speaker was from Buz, which, according to Jeremiah 25:23 was near Tema and Dedan. A young man, he impetuously and impatiently upbraids Job for his boldness toward God, and the three friends for not successfully answering Job. He undertakes to defend God's absolute justice and to explain more clearly why there is suffering. While fundamentally his position is the same as that of the three friends, he does locate more definitely, though not perfectly, the place of suffering in the divine plan.

verses.1:
Job
Introduction
The Book of Job, named after its protagonist, is an exquisite dramatic poem which treats of the problem of the suffering of the innocent, and of retribution. The contents of the book, together with its artistic structure and elegant style, place it among the literary masterpieces of all time
Job, an oriental chieftain, pious and upright, richly endowed in his own person and in domestic prosperity, suffers a sudden and complete reversal of fortune. He loses his property and his children; a loathsome disease afflicts his body; and sorrow oppresses his soul. Nevertheless, Job does not complain against God. When some friends visit him to condole with him, Job protests his innocence and does not understand why he is afflicted. He curses the day of his birth and longs for death to bring an end to his sufferings. The debate which ensues consists of three cycles of speeches. Job's friends insist that his plight can only be a punishment for personal wrongdoing and an invitation from God to repentance. Job rejects their inadequate explanation and calls for a response from God himself. At this point the speeches of a youth named Elihu (Job 32-37) interrupt the development
In response to Job's plea that he be allowed to see God and hear from him the cause of his suffering, God answers, not by justifying his action before men, but by referring to his own omniscience and almighty power. Job is content with this. He recovers his attitude of humility and trust in God, which is deepened now and strengthened by his experience of suffering
The author of the book is not known; it was composed some time between the seventh and fifth centuries B.C. Its literary form, with speeches, prologue and epilogue disposed according to a studied plan, indicates that the purpose of the writing is didactic. The lesson is that even the just may suffer here, and their sufferings are a test of their fidelity. They shall be rewarded in the end. Man's finite mind cannot probe the depths of the divine omniscience that governs the world. The problems we encounter can be solved by a broader and deeper awareness of God's power, presence ( Job 42:5) and wisdom
The divisions of the Book of Job are as follows
I. Prologue ( Job 1:1- 2:13)
II. First Cycle of Speeches ( Job 3:1- 14:22)
III. Second Cycle of Speeches ( Job 15:1- 21:34)
IV. Third Cycle of Speeches ( Job 22:1- 28:28)
V. Job's Final Summary of His Cause ( Job 29:1- 31:37)
VI. Elihu's Speeches ( Job 32:1- 37:24)
VII. The Lord's Speech ( Job 38:1- 42:6)
VIII. Epilogue ( Job 42:7-17)
